title: Waverley, or, T́is sixty years since /
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: But next day a formal Gazette was circulated, containing a detailed account of the battle of Gladsmuir, as the Highlanders chose to denominate their victory. It concluded with an account of the court aftei-wards held by the Chevalier at Pinkie House, which contained this among other high-flown descrijjtive jiaragraphs :

title: A physician's vacation;
author: Channing, Walter 1786-1876. [from old catalog]
snippet: At a later time, in '45, Charles Stuart established himself here, after the battle of Preston Pans, and held his court in the Great Hall. Somerset, after his victory of Musselburgh, held court in the Great Hall of Pinkie House. But how great is the change.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
snippet: 2 Musselburgh. The castle referred to is probably Pinkie House, which dates from the reign of James VI. The river is, of course, the Esk.

title: A physician's vacation;
author: Channing, Walter 1786-1876. [from old catalog]
snippet: The patient was very fleshy; and appeared to suffer nothing from disease. A dinner engagement was in hand, and at about six we dressed, and set off for Pinkie House in Musselburgh, six or more miles from Edinburgh. Now this is a Castle, but in no sense a ruin.

title: Waverley, or, T́is sixty years since /
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: At this moment Fergus pushed into the press. "Come, p]dward, come along; the Prince has gone to Pinkie House for the night ; and we must follow, or lose the whole ceremony of tlie cjtl'vjiv. Your friend, the Baron, has been guilty of a great piece of cruelty ; lie has insisted upon dragging liiiilie Maxiwheeble out to the held of battle.

title: Waverley, or, T́is sixty years since /
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " I WAS turned back, " said Fergus to Edward, as they galloped from Preston to Pinkie House, " by a message from the Prince. But 1 suppose you know the value of this most noble Colonel Talbot as a prisoner.

title: Waverley, or, T́is sixty years since /
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: ' Charles Edward took up his quarters after the battle at Pinkie House, adjoiaing to Musselburgh.

title: A physician's vacation;
author: Channing, Walter 1786-1876. [from old catalog]
snippet: Pinkie House is distinguished for its historical associations. It was concerned in the civil wars, and its large hall was a hospital for the wounded in the great battle of Pinkie, which was fought between the armies of Charles I. and Cromwell.

title: A physician's vacation;
author: Channing, Walter 1786-1876. [from old catalog]
snippet: I have everywhere met with a cordial welcome from those whose acquaintance I have made in these distant lands. I shall place among the chiefest of those the family in Pinkie House, and I trust I shall not forget the visit I made there. I have said little of that or those things which are related to the domestic life of such a place.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: The sheltered situation of the town at the bottom of the valley of the Esk, and the ornamental character of the environs, giveit a veiy agreeable appearance. Pinkie House, the seat of Sir Archibald Hope, Bart., is here, and behind the shrubberies of this house is where the battle of Pinkie was fought in 1547. Fisberrow is altogether inhabited by fishermen, and bere the celebrated Scotch fish-wife may be seen on ber "native heath."
